msItemStruct.note: Catalogue no. 40; Nelson collection no. N300. No date given. Pales is Muhs' Taxpayer 35. 1/2 silver kite 1 obol, or 7 obols, was the usual payment for the burial tax on the interment of one individual in the necropolis in the second half of the reign of Ptolemy III. The scribe Mires, son of Petosiris was responsible for two other burial tax receipts from Thebes (O. Birbeh 3 and O. TT 373 doc. 2367; Devauchelle 1998 and Vleeming 1994), perhaps one burial plot receipt (DO Louvre 314; Devauchelle 1983), read as "Hr-rsn(?)..." and perhaps one salt tax receipt (DO Leiden 2; Nur el-Din 1974), read as "... sa Pay-wsir(?)." Mires apparently did not like to waste space because both O. Birbeh 3 and this ostracon have a second receipt on the verso and only one of his receipts (O. Birbeh 3 verso) mentions a year 24, probably of Ptolemy III.
